params.textField: Referencing enables you to demonstrate the *evidence* that you have used in your work. Without referencing, you risk committing *plagiarism*. This means passing off someone else's work or ideas as your own. Plagiarism is a serious *academic offense*.

params.question: At Newman, the type of referencing used is called "Newman Harvard", which is a type of in-text referencing.

questions:
There are *two* places you must references. 

These are, firstly *in-text*, which is referencing inside your essay or PowerPoint, within the text. 

Secondly, you must reference at the end of your work in the *reference list*.

answers.text: Plagiarism can happen accidentally, while you are getting used to referencing - it takes practice
Plagiarism can happen if you're in a hurry and don't keep track of where your evidence came from
Plagiarism can happen if you're not confident in what you've written about, perhaps if you have not done enough reading or research.

params.question: What are some of the reasons plagiarism might occur?

params.textField: To avoid plagiarism, it is helpful to understand what plagiarism is. It is also important manage information carefully, so that you can keep track of where *evidence comes from*. There is a helpful *library referencing guide* that will help with referencing correctly. Finally, make use of the support available, including *library workshops*.
